text:
Hi, everyone. So my name is Jasmine. And this lecture will be
a little bit unorthodox,

because today happens
to coincide with the day that the Vision Pro releases. So, yeah, the first half
will be just an overview

of augmented and virtual
reality and previous projects. And then the latter half will
be current research that moves

beyond what was done before. And so I entitled it
From Flat to Phantasmal because I think, as
interaction designers,

we specifically now need
to think from the xy- to the xyz-coordinate. And phantasmal is actually
a nod to a very good book

that I would recommend
by Fox Harrell, who's the head of the Center
for Virtuality at MIT, called Phantasmal Media.

So nod to him. And so this is the
traditional taxonomy.

It was actually in 1992 by
a mechanical engineering professor, ironically.

And I'm sure you've
all seen this, but I just want to
recap of the difference between virtual reality
versus augmented reality

and augmented
virtual virtuality. Virtual reality is where there
is a digital environment,

digital assets. Augmented virtuality
is where you are bringing something that's
tangible into digital space.

It's actually probably the
most interesting one visually. Augmented reality is where you
are embedding digital objects

in real space. And then real reality
is a consensual reality that we're all in right now.

Hopefully, I don't know. We could be in a simulation. And this is all
called mixed reality.

I think there's a
misnomer that's going on, as people are referring to pass
through augmented reality, which

is basically a double
rendering because you're taking a video of the
environment, which is

technically what a phone does. And then embedding digital
objects on top of that. That's being called
mixed reality.

But really it is passed
through augmented reality, according to this taxonomy. So I just wanted
to make that clear.

Yes. And so spatial computing,
which Apple rebranded, because before we just referred
to it as AR, VR, XR, SR.

Some sort of prescription
drug, like acronym. It comprises a lot
of different fields.

And I would say that the most
notable one is computer graphics since that's the origin of
the field in and of itself,

with Tom Furness
who is, I think, now at university of Washington. Of course, on the hardware
side, it involves optics.

Now we're seeing how you
can add contextualization by integrating AIML. Of course, we're here
for HCI, but a lot

of the underlying technology
centers around games. Psychology and
neuroscience is something

that will become increasingly
important in the next 5 to 10 years, thinking about how people
interact with these devices,

specifically. I think meta had done some
precursor work with horizons, but I think now there's probably
a more garnered interest.

And so that's going to be a
very lucrative and needed field

of study. And, of course, sensors,
which is how we are able to perceive our environment.

And so a lot of people ask me-- and I think anybody
should ask this questions. OK, well, how did
you get into AR/VR?

And so, actually, in
undergrad-- it's very strange. But in undergrad, I
was studying chemistry

because I wanted
to be a perfumer. So really, I wanted
to be a perfumer. So I was double majoring
in chemistry and French.

Please don't ask me--
please do not-- please do not ask me to speak French,
especially if you're a Parisian, because they're very
critical of the intonation.

But when I took this class-- I was amazed by
this because I think the way that we
perceive color is

we perceive color as additive. But this is the
Briggs-Rauscher reaction, which is a redox reaction where
the concentration of iodine

changes. And those of you that are
bioengineers or in the life sciences are aware
of this reaction.

And it sort of just-- I think it challenged my
perception of what color is. And so I remember
asking my professor, OK,

how do I actually
understand what's going on? Because how does this change
from a dark blue color

to a clear color? Because that completely
ruins my perception of what I thought color was. And he's like, well,
to answer that, you

need to actually take quantum
physics to really understand. So then I switched
my major to physics,

because I really
wanted to understand. And I actually ended up adding
on an electrical engineering

degree because I found it
fascinating for similar reasons. It's fascinating--
we'll get into that,

if you have questions later. But, yeah, I think that this
interaction changed the nature

of perception for me. And I wanted to know
why because it just made the natural world
seem more interesting. And then you find out that the
reason why the colors change is

basically because in transition
metals, there's d orbitals. And the way that light
interacts with those d orbitals

is why it reflects color. So completely different than
the visible light spectrum that we're accustomed to.

And I think it
set the foundation of me questioning
the nature of what reality is in and of itself.

And so kind of extending
on that chemistry metaphor, another
question that gets asked is, OK,
well, I've seen AR.

AR has been around
since the '80s. And why hasn't it
caught traction yet? Because a lot of people
ask that question.

And so for me, I made an
activation energy chart, if you will. So activation energy
is the energy that's

needed for a chemical reaction. But for me, it's the
energy needed for people to actually care
about the technology

and to have a retention
in the experiences. So a lot of what happens is--

I don't know if you've
downloaded AR app. So how many of you
have downloaded AR apps, specifically
mobile ones or Quest apps

on the Quest store? Especially with
phone-based AR apps, what happens is
that onboarding is

very difficult because a
lot of branded experience, they'll present a QR code. You scan that QR code,
and then that QR code

takes you to either the App
Store or the Play Store. So by the time
you've already had to navigate throughout those
three screens, you're tired,

and you're not even interested
in the experience anymore. And so onboarding is actually
probably the key issue.

And when I say onboarding,
I mean the initial, I guess,

scanning or starting of
the app versus to basically understanding the different
controls in an experience.

And I think that's
where a lot of people have fallen off, because
they'll get into a VR experience or an AR experience,
not intuitively understand

the controls. And then they drop off. And so I think
that's the problem.

And so for me, I think that-- there are headsets,
but I think it's important to note that 84-point
whatever percent of the world's

population owns a smartphone. And so a lot of
times, we can use that as a segue to get people
into exploring these mixed

reality technologies. And it's a more accessible way
of exploring these technologies.

And so the way that I
see how a phone actually can interact with these
mixed reality experiences

is in terms of three
different ways. So as a window, a
scanner, and a controller.

And so in the subsequent slides,
I will show examples of each because there are
many examples of each.

And I thought about what are the
three use cases for mobile AR. And this is kind of
what was converged on.

So I don't know if
you've seen any of these. So I also gave reference
to who made them.

Let me play this one as well. And so as a window,
it's basically a portal into another digital realm.

A window can also be
looking at different scales. It can be looking at different,
I guess you would say, layers.

There's a lot of
biology simulations that take advantage of this. And then this last one can also
be for visualization as well

into things that we cannot
readily perceive like audio.

OK. So the second one, let me-- the
second one, which is a scanner,

is also a very apt
use of a mobile phone. And so now there's Luma Labs.

I had replaced that
with something else. But what you can do is you
can just scan the phone, and that's how-- use
the phone as a scanner,

and that's how you're able
to perceive the environment. And I think the most-- I think this is the
most obvious one

because that's how the
Depth API and all these APIs work in the first place. But I think you
can actually use it

as Land Labs did in
this bottom corner as an actual object scanner. And that was something
that was done at Unity,

which I will explain later. And the other one
that's very interesting is using a phone
as a controller,

because the Vision Pro doesn't
have a controller, as we know. But I think people are just
so used to the mental model

interaction of a phone. So using the phone as a proxy
to a controller, I think,

will be very useful
in the present. And just to note,
Qualcomm has actually

implemented this sort
of controller paradigm on their Snapdragon framework. So I would go and look at that.

Yeah. And so speaking of
scanner, I guess

the most used work that I've
ever implemented and done was at Google working
on the Depth API.

So I wasn't originally
supposed to work on it, but what happened is that
a lot of AR/VR expertise

is understaffed. So they needed someone who is
familiar with Unity, familiar with AR/VR. And I was like, I'm definitely
the person for the task.

And so I help the
Google research team in implementing the Depth API. And so the Depth API, again,
provides a scene understanding

of the environment
via parallax motion, as opposed to the iPhone
which uses LiDAR scanning.

And so again, it
makes it accessible to every android
device so you don't have to buy the $1,000 iPhone to
get the same augmented reality

experiences. And so this was something that
was a Depth API experience.

I want to note that this doesn't
show occlusion or collision, because that was one of the
prime features of the Depth

API, which if you've looked at
filters like at Snapchat, Snap, or Spark, it uses the
depth API as well.

But one thing that was
interesting is, a lot of times when people are authoring
an AR, it's very difficult.

There was a Minecraft
AR experience that was deprecated after
maybe a year and a half, because people get
fatigued having

to place objects individually. So then we wanted to make an
open-source experience that

was like, OK, if
people wanted to level edit an augmented reality
quickly, how can they do that? And then the answer
is like you can

make a path of clones in
familiar shapes like in vector programs. So if I wanted a
ring of mushrooms,

you can just make the ring. If I wanted a free-form
ring of clones of objects, I can do that.
And so it expedites the process. And that's open sourced--

so we'd look at that. So one thing-- this
is implemented, but these were
just the mockups--

is that I think a lot of-- when people think of
AI, they immediately associate it with
LLMs now, right?

But I think object detection,
especially for AR/VR, will be extremely
important, if we're

talking about contextualizing
and adding information. And so one of my favorite little
mini experiments that I did was,

you're scanning
objects in the room. So book, for instance. And then what it
does is it has--

it pulls from a
database of books. And it basically finds
a quote in a book that

contains the object, right? So with this one, I
think it's pulling from Alice in Wonderland. And since it detected
that there was tea,

it then pulls a quote
from Alice in Wonderland. So it just makes
things more fun.

And today, people don't
really like to read. So it forces people to
look at literary quotes

that they normally
wouldn't have looked at. And then this is the
research that's current.

The research is called Speaking
the World into Existence. I did not have any say
in what it was called,

because I would give that
honor to Jaron Lanier, who is one of the pioneers
of virtual reality.

He actually came up with
the term "virtual reality" in the '80s with his lab. And Speaking of the
World into Existence

is obviously a nod to the
act of creation, right? So almost every story,
let there be light.

It's also definitely
in African, Chinese. Most mythologies,
the world is spoken,

because speaking is
like an incantation. But also when you speak,
there's a level of agency

that's expected, which you
don't really get with LLMs, if you've played
around with LLMs.

And so this was the
first paper, which was called Step Towards
Prompt-Based Creation of Virtual

Worlds. And there's Jaron
and another person that I've worked with, Andy. And essentially, what we did was
we experimented and prototyped

where our large
language models useful, where are they not
mixing deterministic and non-deterministic components.

Because, essentially,
hallucination is not game design,
because then the LLM

is designing the
experience for you. But if lucid dreaming means
that I have 100% control,

the machine hallucinating
means that it has control, and I'm prompting it.

And I've showed this slide
before to some people. But I think a lot of
people also wonder, OK,

where does this data come from? Why is this so difficult
to do specifically in the context of virtual
and augmented reality, which

are built on game engines? And a lot of that
comes down to where the data is being pulled from.

So most of the code
that's being pulled is from Github, which should
not be a surprise, which is open-source code.

And so you'll see things where
people are happy like, oh, look, I made Pong in JavaScript.

I hope you did because there's
about 90k repositories of Pong. So it's just replicate--
or, oh, I made breakout.

The thing is, if the game
has a level of craftsmanship and detail, that really
still can't be achieved

with generative AI alone. You still need bespoke assets. You still need the
technical artists.

You still need a team
to implement that. But I think there was a
cycle, maybe a few months ago,

where people were
under the impression that they can create
full-fledged games of their design using
generative AI alone.

And so one thing
that we found that was good to use for generative
AI and it's a very simple call,

too, is-- how many of you have worked
with 3D assets before?

Yeah. So you know that 3D
assets are frustrating, especially if you're trying to
receive them from the artist.

So I'll ask for a Teddy bear. And then I get the Teddy bear. It's two meters tall, but it
needs to be in real-world scale.

So one thing that we
found that is a good use case of generative AI is
just to do a call to ChatGPT,
which was called Codex. It changes every week. It seems what it's called. But Codex at the time--

of, OK, if I'm importing
an apple and I know it's apple because it's
been tagged by the artist,

then how big is an apple
in real-world scale? And then it's able to
import that directly

into Unity or Unreal, taking
into account their coordinate systems.
And I'll give an example. This is in black and white.

Here we go. So I typed in orca whale,
which is redundant. But bear with me.

And so then it has to produce
the orca whale to scale. And you're like, ah! Then if you look
on that hand side, you're like, what's going on?

But then if you zoom out,
you see that he's actually nested in the whale. So he's Jonah. So again, making those
biblical references.

And then another thing that
we've done is just a Holodeck experience or a
toy-world experience,

which is something that-- a team I had worked
with had called, and I thought it was a
really interesting name--

which is how to position
objects properly in space. And so you would already
have a repository of assets.

But then you could tell
it, OK, I want a couch. I want books here. I want an apple
on top of a table.

I want a couch in this corner. And then also, if you
look, I think the most--

I don't have a pointer. But if you look, you can see the
little two images on the wall. Those two images on
the wall were actually

generated with DALL-E. Yeah. So the thing is, you
can have the frame and then nest it in the frame.

Those are actually--
that's actually DALL-E that's integrated
into Unity in the frames.

And so exploring those
sort of interactions. So the most interesting
thing, I think, that was done

is we wanted to pay homage
to Pong, which technically was the first game that was
done on an oscilloscope up

in Berkeley. And we developed a
multiplayer Pong game, where

there were deterministic parts. So I was able to
say, change paddle.

It knew to prompt the paddle. If I said, play something,
which you can see in the video, it would place it
directly where I looked.

Change ball, it would change
the projectile or the ball. If I pause, the entire
game would pause.

Continue, it'd continue. Pull, pull. And it's also-- if
you're familiar with, put this or put that there by
Chris Schmandt, very similar

interaction paradigm to that. But if you look at this one--
this is still my favorite one. I show this one
all the time, which

is, if you change
your hand to a knife and then you change
the ball to salmon

and then look what
happens-- oh, no! Look what happens
when you collide. And then also there was lag. And then also notice
how it's orthogonal.

We fixed that. And then it changes to
sushi because it knows--

well, it doesn't know. But that's sort of-- if you ever
played the game Little Alchemy, which I would say is sort
of an ontology engine--

so it's able to say, OK,
if I get water and fire, what do I get?

Right? Or if I get-- just any two objects. If I do a banana and apple,
usually, it'll produce smoothie.

But I think exploring these
sorts of combinatorial dynamics are interesting because it's
not just about the game play.

It's also you're discovering
what data is actually in the model, right? And I think because that's
where you're like, OK,

what data is this grounded in? Because another one
that I always reference is, I remember
after I had combined

the banana and the apple
and it made a smoothie, the smoothie had been
bouncing towards me. I was like, OK, let me
change my paddle to a mango.

So then I had
mango and smoothie. And for me, for my
frame of reference, I really thought it was
going to do mango lassi.

It did not do mango lassi. It did smoothie again. So I said, man, it doesn't
even know what mango lassi is.

And so then I had to
keep adding things. I was like, OK, if I add
cardamom, will it somehow know? Just like any-- and it did know.

It then knew with
the additional input, but it's clearly
grounded in English.

And I think that was just
further proof of that. So I think just thinking of
games as ontology engines

instead of thinking of
them in very defined terms, because I think people
think that game design, game

discourse, and game pedagogy
is at odds with HCR or computer science pedagogy.

And because I've navigated
the different spaces and have met different
people, a lot of people

are thinking along
the same lines. There just doesn't seem
to be cross pollination. So when this year--

we were reviewing
[? CHI ?] papers, and there was a game track. And one thing that
I had noticed-- and I'm saying this because
you all are-- most of you

are students-- is that
a lot of the work that was done that was presented
had actually been done before

but not by people that had
submitted to ACM SIGCHI conferences, but had submitted
to games conferences like IEEE

CoG or these other conferences. So this is just to say-- to remember to be cognizant
of other research.

And when you do a literary
review with AR/VR, make sure that you're
looking at things outside

of the conferences that
you're applying to. Yeah. And so, essentially,
how this was done,

it's not special anymore. It was special maybe a few
months ago, but now that--

what is it? Pocket Pals and Palworld
and all those companies are attempting this.

The novelty has been diluted. But, essentially,
integrating OpenAI's models

into game engine--
or not just OpenAI. Any sort of LLM model
into game engines is frustrating, if you
want it to run runtime.

# Because C# is not a
scripted language, right? It's an interpreted language. So it's easier to use,
say, Babylon.js to--

if you want to use Babylon.js
to produce generative AR/VR experiences, that's easy because
it's trained on more data.

# I think for C#, Github has
about maybe 7% C# code. # Unity also is clearly a
derivative of C# using

the MonoDevelop framework. And so to even do this, you
have to put a compiler in Unity

called-- we use the Roslyn
compiler to even get all this to run runtime. And so that was just
what this was about.

And now it's open source. So if you go on my Github,
you can just fork it. But before, it was
more under wraps.

And again, returning to
[? MyROOTs, ?] one thing that

I'm working on now, because
[? MyROOTs ?] is I'm very-- I still am interested
in physics and dynamics

and just how the
natural world works. Because I think
what's happened now is people now can generate
static objects, right?

We are at a point now with
[? Nerfs ?] and everything, where you can just
present a scene.

And it's hyperrealistic because
this field has moved super fast. But one thing
that's still missing

is how objects interact
with each other, like the interstitial
interactions between objects.

And that's something that
I'm passionate about. And so one thing
I was doing was,

I was thinking, OK, how do
I get ChatGPT to understand what gum is in a game engine?

Like how do I get
it to understand? So there are actually a lot
of databases, material science

databases, where you see-- where there's a lot
of different variables like elasticity,
thermal properties,

mechanical properties. So bringing that
data which really hasn't been used
in generative AI,

and then pulling that in so
that we can replicate that. Because I feel like
once you actually are able to replicate
physics of objects,

that's when you actually are
able to get that lucid dreaming. Because now, essentially,
a lot of, I guess,

the work that you see is
just static objects, right? There's no dynamism.

And then even when there is a
character model that's animated, again, it doesn't really have
any semantic understanding

of what's around it. So it's not like it's
able to do anything. And so, yeah, this is something
that I'm very passionate about,

and I would love to answer
questions about this. And, yeah, relatively short.
But that's it. [APPLAUSE]

All right, we've got some time
for questions, discussion.

Can you say a little bit more
about the psychology [INAUDIBLE]

5 to 10 years [INAUDIBLE]? Yeah, there's actually a lot. So what do you want to
know about, specifically? Because there's the-- there's
I would say the social VR

side of things. There's the actual
biometric integrations that CTRL-Labs, which is a
subsidiary of meta is doing.
So just curious which angle. Both [? are interesting. ?] Both? OK.

Yeah. I would say that social VR-- yeah, social VR is definitely
going to be more explored.

I think-- again, I
think the problem is that a lot of
the research has been done in industry
instead of in academia.

And one of my qualms that
I have with the industry is I think that academia,
since you're all in one--

you're on one campus,
so you're able to have cross-discipline
collaboration that doesn't happen as much as you
would like to in tech companies.

And so a lot of those things
about ethics and psychology and human-to-human
interaction were lost.

And what happens when that--
what happens when you don't take into consideration [? that ?]
the environments become toxic,

they're not pleasant
to be in, you get 13-year-olds who
are using expletives. And that's something that
does have to be explored.

I can say that there are people
I know who specialize in this. And they're actually
both at Apple,

for whatever that's worth. So I think that work
is being done there. Meta is doing that work. And then there's
also a lot of work

that you can pull from
Second Life, right? Just Second Life, the
original Second Life that actually shows
how people interact

and how they perceive their
identity and how they-- and almost like how people--

I guess it's like how people-- like how people not
only just choose avatars

but why they choose the
avatars they choose. Is it an idealized
version of them,

or they-- because
the way that people interact with
gaming technologies is very different, right?

Some people are purely
in an experience just to communicate with others. You would call that a social
experiment or a social user.

The second group is people
who are more explorers, right? So it's the people
who play games. And they try to exploit
flaws in a gaming map, which

I've done on Left 4 Dead, too,
which might reveal my age. But, anyway-- And then also there's achiever.

So people who like gaining
something from playing the game, whether that's like collecting
coins and just the leaderboard

and showing their friends. And then I think
the fourth one is-- achievers, socializers-- oh,
people who like FPS games.

I almost forgot that. People killers. They're called killers. In the Bartle model
of games, that's

actually what it's called. So, yeah, there has been
research done into this. I mean, a lot of
research of that vein

is being done here in the
communications department. That's a lot of
[? Fox's ?] research.

I would say in terms of the
bio research with neuroscience,

there's a company
called OpenBCI, which was a-- an alum of the
[? MediaLab, ?] [? Connor ?] had

worked on that. Facebook bought CTRL-Labs. CTRL-Labs was its own
company in New York,

but now it's a subsidiary. And, yeah, there's a lot
of work on-- essentially, the work that I'm doing--
but instead of voice

being the input, you
would actually just have thoughts be the input. There's a lot of work on that. So I would look into that.

It's CTRL-Labs' control. I would look-- just reference
CTRL-Labs for the papers.

Thank you so much for your talk. I was curious when you
spoke about controllers.

I think with the new
Apple Vision Pro, we see this move towards just
using your hands and using--

without having any
controllers out there. But I found some aspects
of it to be unnatural like, for example, typing on
a keyboard with your fingers.

So how do you think
input is going to evolve? Do you think it's
going to be all speech? Do you think there's a
better way to get about it?

Yeah, no. It can't be all
speech, because one of the great things
about tech is that there's like a
diversity of people

that work in tech who don't have
English as a primary language. And that's an impediment
to voice-only systems.

I will say that there
are a lot of teams that are working
on haptic gloves, because haptics are important.

And that's why that keyboard
experience on the Vision Pro doesn't feel real.

And I find it a little bit
interesting because even the older VR systems
in the '90s, like you saw at NASA or [? Jahren's ?]
Lab, they had haptic gloves.

But I think in this
last iteration of AR/VR, for some reason,
people weren't-- they weren't
prioritizing haptics.

Yeah. Yeah. So thank you so
much for your talk.

You mentioned that
physics of objects can lead to lucid dreaming. What does that exactly mean?
Yeah. I think-- OK. OK, I'll try to give an example. So if I just say I want a--
give me any object. Like an apple? Oh, man.

OK, OK. Well, see this
actually can be done. But, fine. OK. So if I say that I want an apple
rendered, I can render an apple.

But it's not necessarily
about objects in the scene. It's about how objects are able
to interact with other objects

in the scene, right? Because that's basically the
nature of what physics are. It's this forces, right? It's like based on the
four fundamental forces.

So the distance between me and
you, me and you, me and you. And so it's about
that interplay, right?

And so what's happening
now is that, again, I could say render an apple. And Luma Labs can
do that quite well.

But if I say something that
even uses colloquialisms like, hey, render an apple and
drop it Newton's style.

Actually, it probably
could figure that out. You would essentially expect
something that's like some

[? y-height ?] and
then to drop in Unity. So that's what
I'm talking about. And that's a simple interaction.

But even looking at
interactions that are playing with shaders
and material properties like the stretching and the
elasticity and the-- yeah.

I'm curious about
the interaction

between [? Mr. ?] And Mrs.
[INAUDIBLE] from academia. There's so much
really good research like-- you give
examples on avatars.

A lot of the work that's coming
out of [? Fox's ?] group. How do you feel like-- as
someone who's in both worlds,

how do you feel like industry
is or is not prioritizing some of that research on
social implications

of spatial computing? Yeah. I think it's a
bilateral thing, right?

I was just telling
